fields.physical_description:
[Box] Long rectangular cardboard box comprising lid, base and inner packaging, covered with textured paper and almost entirely painted gold. The lid has a small 'Monopoly' logo in navy, in the top left corner, and the bottom of the base is covered with plain white paper.
[Play money] Cardboard box with 10 compartments, covered with textured paper and painted gold. There is a looped red ribbon on either side to lift it out of the main box, and red ribbons emerging from 7 of the compartments for ease of removing the notes or cards contained. It is designed to hold the play money, houses, hotels, cards and playing pieces of the game.
[Community Chest cards] Square game board which folds in half to fit in box. The back is covered with textured paper painted gold with the Monopoly logo painted on one side in navy. When unfolded the game board features the general Monopoly board, with a pale green background and 40 spaces around the board featuring the areas of London that you can buy. The central area features the Monopoly logo and spaces for the Chance and Community Chest game cards.
[Chance cards] Paper rectangles printed with a pattern in black ink, featuring different denominations in a central oval and top left and bottom right rectangles, with a steam train engine shape in the top right and house shape in the bottom left rectangles, designed to resemble bank notes. There are 70 '1' notes on pale yellow paper,  92 '5's on pale blue, 137 '10's on white, 40 '20's on green, 52 '50's on lilac, 80 '100's on orange and 20 '500's printed in red ink on white paper.
[Houses] 16 yellow cardboard playing cards with rounded corners, each printed on one side with the title 'COMMUNITY CHEST' and an instruction to play in the game.   
[Hotels] 16 dark orange cardboard playing cards with rounded corners, each printed on one side with the title 'CHANCE' and an instruction to play in the game.   
[Dice] 32 green bakelite house playing pieces, heptahedrons with a square base with sloping roof.
[Tokens] 12 red bakelite hotel playing pieces, heptahedrons with a square base with sloping roof, printed in gold ink on the two longer fascias with "GRAND / HOTEL" and an image of an entrance and a window either side.
[Instruction leaflets] Two translucent red bakelite cuboid dice with indented markings painted white.
[Advertisement] Pewter tokens representing each player on the board: this set includes a 1930s style car, a bathtub, a candlestick, a tram car, a rocking horse, a lantern with a transparent plastic insert, and a chalice with a translucent green plastic insert.
[Title deed cards] Two identical instruction leaflets, black typography on one square sheet folded in half to make four pages, featuring the monopoly logo at the top, and an additional small sheet with instructions for playing the 'New Short Game'.

fields.title: Monopoly
fields.materials_techniques: [Box] Gold-painted textured paper-covered cardboard box lid, box base and inner packaging.
fields.marks:
[Box] Monopoly
[Play money] MONOPOLY / PAT. APP. FOR NO. 3796-36
fields.public_access_description:
This is a rare Super Gold Monopoly set from 1936, when Monopoly was first manufactured in the UK by Waddingtons under licence from Parker Bros. in the USA. The game box and board have been painted gold, and the now commonly known playing pieces (a top hat, a dog, a wheel barrow, an iron, a boot, a race car, a battleship and a thimble) are instead a 1930s style car, a lantern, a rocking horse, a chalice, a tram car, a candlestick and a bathtub, although the object of the game remains the same. 

Monopoly is one of the most recognisable games in the world, having sold more than 275 million games since it was first marketed in the 1930s, with specific editions produced for many countries, and many diffferent licenced and limited edition versions having been designed (including Star Wars, Harry Potter and Dr Seuss's The Cat in the Hat). It is well known for its long playing time and current licence owner Hasbro says that the longest game recorded lasted for 70 days, although there are theoretical possibilities recorded on Monopoly fan websites that suggest the game can be won in less than 30 seconds!
